Construction Update

If you have visited Fairview recently, you likely have taken notice that construction is nearing the completion stage. The crew is working on finishing up some exterior work, which should be done shortly. Inside, final painting is being done and floors are being waxed. Crews are working on safety aspects, such as door buzzers and fire alarms. The crew is also working on the heating and cooling system, and hopes to test it out next week.

If everything continues to go as planned, it is possible that Mr. O’Malley and Mrs. Halle could leave their trailer and occupy the office in early March. Once the office is established and things are running smoothly, other staff members will be able to follow suit. It shouldn’t be too long before the entire new addition will be up and running.

We will be sure to keep you posted as your new school opens up!

FV 4th grade students had the opportunity to work with a Plymouth School District alumni, Suzanne Kaufman. Suzanne is back in the area to present at the Sheboygan Children's Book Festival this weekend. The 4th grade students enjoyed learning how to draw faces on people.

Here is some information about Suzanne
Suzanne Kaufman is the Illustrator of the New York Times best-selling picture book All Are Welcome. She is an author, illustrator, animator and lover of school potlucks. She has written and illustrated her own books Confiscated and I Love Monkey. Her previous illustration work includes: Take Your Pets to School Day, 100 Bugs, Naughty Claudine Christmas, and Samanthasaurus Rex. She is the recipient of The Ezra Jack Keats/Kerlan Memorial Fellowship, Mentorship and Portfolio Honors from the Society of Children’s Book Writers and Illustrators.

Practice eating “school lunch” with your child. Make sure they can open everything you send them with. Talk about not eating off the table in the lunchroom. Set a timer for 15 minutes and talk about how they may not finish eating and that’s ok. Practice packing everything back up and ran about what is trash and what should come back home in their lunch box. Lunch, especially for Kindergartners is a big adjustment and your child’s teacher will be super appreciative of you have prepared them for the experience!
